ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to better read theory of all kinds. I've also gained a strong knowledge of film theory. Ineffable skills important for all film majors.

A wide perspective of the film theory field throughout the past century, through early idealism, montage theory, early film psychology, neorealism, phenomenology, Freudian psychoanalysis, feminist and critical perspectives.
Understanding films relationship to reality, cognition, other art forms and media

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses. Possibly the most helpful class I've taken at Yale. This should be a requirement within the film and media studies major.
Amazing class. Great professor, made me excited to get up for 9ams. Great readings, great films, great conversations. No weaknesses

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course to both film majors and non-film majors, although I think for a film major this should be a requirement. I learned so much--I have a strong understanding of canonically important film theory, and of how to use that theory to become a better viewer of films. I have become a better reader and watcher.
Yes! Best class ever for people who like thinking about the medium of film on a high intellectual level.
